body.p: The IASB decided that these differences do not justify applying a different impairment model and therefore included lease receivables within the scope of the impairment requirements in IFRS 9. In reaching this decision, the IASB concluded that the impairment model could be applied to lease receivables as long as:

li.p: the cash flows assessed for expected credit losses are consistent with those included in the measurement of the lease receivable; and
the rate used to discount the expected credit losses is consistent with the rate that is determined in accordance with IAS 17.
